c74object.name: bach.repeat
c74object.description: Repeats an incoming llll a certain number of times.

objarg.name: number_of_repetitions
objarg.description: The optional argument sets the initial number of repetitions (the default is 1).

method.name: bang
method.description: Repeats the most recently received input llll.

method.name: int
method.description: A non-negative integer in the second inlet sets the number of times the incoming llll must be repeated.

method.name: llll
method.description: An llll in the first inlet will be repeated a certain number of times (defined by the number in the right inlet or by the argument), and then output through the outlet. For instance, repeating foo (fee faa) three times will yield foo (fee faa) foo (fee faa) foo (fee faa). Via the inwrap and outwrap attributes you can add level of parenthesis for each individual repetition or for the whole output llll, which allows you to obtain more complicate output lllls, such as (((foo (fee faa))) ((foo (fee faa))) ((foo (fee faa)))).

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, e

attribute.name: unwrap
attribute.description: Wrap every output llll in the correspongind number of parentheses. This is equivalent to connecting a bach.wrap object to every llll outlet.

c74object.discussion: The repetitions could be individually wrapped or globally wrapped, thanks to the inwrap and outwrap attributes

entry.name: More details
entry.description: The repetitions could be individually wrapped or globally wrapped, thanks to the inwrap and outwrap attributes
